These texts and images may not be used for any commercial purpose without prior written permission from Romantic Circles.
These texts and images may not be re-distributed in any forms other than their current ones.

Users are not permitted to download these texts and images in order to mount them on their own servers. Institutions can, of course, make a link to the copies at Romantic Circles, subject to our conditions of use.

hyphenation.p: All dashes have been represented with an emdash: —, and surrounding whitespace has been deleted (except where dash is preceded by a full stop).

quotation.p: All quotation marks and apostrophes have been changed: " for “," for ”, ' for ‘, and ' for ’.

normalization.p: Incorrect and idiosyncratic spelling has not been regularised; instances are marked by a sic element.

taxonomy.bibl: NINES categories for Genre and Material Form at http://www.performantsoftware.com/nines_wiki/index.php/Submitting_RDF#.3Cnines:genre.3E on 2009-02-26

list.item: Minor changes and corrections of Deborah K. Wright's initial encoding.
Some further changes: matter omitted from performance; editorial notes for illegible text; changes to cast list.
Some further changes, including adding to the cast list to account for the Chorus, other changes/comments in response to Justin's questions/comments.
One minor change - removing superfluous square brackets from transcription, and adding tags to deleted word.
Several minor changes: I have inserted corrections to the transcript that were identified by Deborah K. Wright after comparison against manuscript images.
Regularisation of speaker names, detailed above in normalization.
Regularisation of dashes to em dashes. Detailed above in hyphenation.
Incorrect and idiosyncratic spellings from ms encoded with sic.

This file is a modification of the original 'gipsy_ms' file. The change consists of the removal of the songs from the file, and the insertion of anchor elements in their stead. The songs are encoded, using parallel segmentation, in a new file entitled 'gipsy_ms_songs.' The dramatis personae list has also been moved to the 'songs' file, simply because it needs to encoded using parallel segmentation as well--an anchor is also provided for this.

div.head:
The Gipsy Prince (Haymarket, 24 July 1801)
Transcribed from MS LA 1329, in the collection of John Larpent, Lord Chamberlain's Examiner of Plays (1778-1824), at the Huntington Library.
Matter omitted from performance is placed in angle brackets < >
Words and phrases inked out illegibly are noted in square brackets; if legible, transcription is given in strikethrough text.
Additions from published versions of the songs are placed in square brackets and marked with superscript [ ]a [ ]b [ ]c indicating the three published versions of the songs:
[ ]a
Thomas Moore, The Gipsy Prince, A Comic Opera in Two Acts, Now Performing with Universal applause at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket, Compos'd & Selected by Michael Kelly (Printed for Michael Kelly, to be had at his Music Warehouse, No. 9 New Lisle Street, Leicester Square, & at all Music Shops [1801]).
[ ]b
Thomas Moore, Songs, Duets, Trios, and Choruses, in the Gipsy Prince, a Musical Entertainment in Two Acts, first performed at the Theatre-Royal, Hay-Market, July 24, 1801. The Overture and Musick Composed and Selected by Mr. Kelly (London: Printed by T. Woodfall, Little Russell Street, Covent Garden, for Mssrs. Cadell and Davies in the Strand, 1801).
[ ]c
The Gipsy Prince; or, The Loves of Don Sebastian de Nurillo, and the Fair Antonia, translated from the Spanish. By C. Moor, Esq. To which is added, The Corsair; or The Italian Nuptials. (London: J. Roach. 1801). 64pp. -- Front. dated Sept. 7, 1801. [BL shelfmark: 12330.e.37.(2.)].

listWit.witness: Transcribed from MS LA 1329, in the collection of John Larpent, Lord Chamberlain's Examiner of Plays (1778-1824), at the Huntington Library.

Thomas Moore, The Gipsy Prince, A Comic Opera in Two Acts, Now Performing with Universal applause at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket, Compos'd & Selected by Michael Kelly (Printed for Michael Kelly, to be had at his Music Warehouse, No. 9 New Lisle Street, Leicester Square, & at all Music Shops [1801]).

Thomas Moore, Songs, Duets, Trios, and Choruses, in the Gipsy Prince, a Musical Entertainment in Two Acts, first performed at the Theatre-Royal, Hay-Market, July 24, 1801. The Overture and Musick Composed and Selected by Mr. Kelly (London: Printed by T. Woodfall, Little Russell Street , Covent Garden, for Mssrs. Cadell and Davies in the Strand, 1801).

The Gipsy Prince; or, The Loves of Don Sebastian de Nurillo, and the Fair Antonia, translated from the Spanish. By C. Moor, Esq. To which is added, The Corsair; or The Italian Nuptials. (London: J. Roach. 1801). 64pp. -- Front. dated Sept. 7, 1801. [BL shelfmark: 12330.e.37.(2.)].

div.head:
The Gipsey Prince
A Musical Entertainment
in
Two Acts
div.p: This Piece, called the Gipsey Prince, is, with the permission of the Right Honourable, the Lord Chamberlain, intended for Representation at the Theatre Royal Hay-market.

docTitle.titlePart:
The Gipsy Prince
a
Musical Piece
in
Two Acts

div.stage:
The Suburbs of Murcia
Peasant Men and Women dancing before a Cottage,
while others sitting at the Door are playing on Mandolins and Singing

lg.l: Happy the hearts that love has blest
With such a tie, so sweet as this:
For all their Nights, are Nights of rest,
And all their days are days of bliss.
And Time shall ne'er their Love eclipse,
Tho' it may steal their fire away;
But, like their roses on their lips,

Their joys shall soften
not decay.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: That's right—frisk it away—there's not a Man in Murcia loves merriment more than Rincon—go on—I'll caper it with the best of you.

sp.speaker: Diego
sp.p: Poh! Here's this troublesome Rincon. What my good Cavallero—still at your old trick of meddling in other people's business?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Ha! How do you do? Why I own I do like to have a hand and a foot in everything going forward – but what are you about? merry-making, eh?

sp.speaker: Diego
sp.p: If we must give you a full Account of ourselves—I am Diego.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Go on—I knew that before —how naturally the fellow puts himself foremost!

sp.speaker: Diego
sp.p: Well—this is Blanch—and we've just been married—are you satisfied now?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Perfectly at my ease—and this is Blanch, eh?

sp.speaker: Blanch
sp.p: Yes, Sir, at your service.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.stage: (With his back to the Husband—sometimes looking round at him and from him to Blanch)
sp.p: Well, Child—to be sure there is a variety of tastes, but in the choosing of a man (looking down at himself)

sp.speaker: Diego
sp.p: What is the fellow at?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: By our lady of the Rock, thou has got a most delicate lip, Child.

sp.speaker: Blanch
sp.p: A pair of them, Sir, at your service.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: At my service—egad, I think I should like to be meddling there too

sp.speaker: Diego
sp.p: To that I have a trifling objection—and so, good bye to you, Master Go-Between. come along, Girls let the thing dance by itself.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p:
Odso—the fellow is as nice about his Wife, as if she was his own property, but we've learn't better things now-a-days. No—No—a man's wife us'd to belong to him
but the Husband now is put away among the moveables.

l.del: My Heart I confess has had amorous fidgets,
For Mollies, and Dollies, and Sukies and Bridgets,
But thanks to my Stars! by some lucky miscarriage,
I've kept my Neck safe from the Halter of Marriage.
My first love was Dame Plumpton, so ample & fat,
Like a map of the World, round-about, & all that,
I tried to persuade her—she said that she wouldn't—
I could never come round her, no curse me, I couldn't.
The next was a nice little ABCdarian,
The Daughter of Lingo, our Parish Grammarian,
But we ne'er could agree in our Love Education,
For she still declin'd, when I wish'd Conjugation.
Then I said to another, if you'll be my Wife,
Like a couple of Bells, we'll ring nicely thro' life,
But, by Jove, if I'd had the ill luck to entrap her,
I'd have found the sweet Bell the dev'l of a Clapper!

div.note: Song 3 ("I remember") appears in witnesses a, b, and c, but not the ms. Click here to compare these witnesses.

div.head: Scene 2nd
div.stage: Discovers Gipsies seated round a Fire in the background. They begin a low, melancholy Dirge

lg.l: Bleak rains may fall or Winds whistle over us,
Nothing but Heaven and darkness to cover us!

sp.stage: Then starting up burst into a lively Chorus.

lg.l: Merry we still fly
Where our fates lead us,
Winter or chill Sky
Cannot impede us. &.c &.c

div.stage: Enter to them the Gipsy Prince in a fanciful half Eastern Dress.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Well, fellows, we are now in Murcia, and near the City. I know not how we strollers are receiv'd in Spain, but I'll on to enquire and be back with you at Night fall.

sp.speaker: 1st Gipsy.
sp.p: Where shall we pitch our Tents?

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Some distance hence among those Willows. This Dress will at all events secure me from suspicion. Away.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Where shall my wanderings and adventures cease? after travelling thro' the World, unknowing and unknown, I now am made a Chief of Vagabonds. Well, well, it matters not where I go. I know no Parent but Nature, and she gives me the World for my home!

lg.l: I've roam'd thro' many a weary round,
I've wander'd East and West;
Pleasure in every Clime I've found,
But sought in vain for rest.
While Glory sighs for other spheres
I feel that one's too wide
And think a home which love endears,
Were worth the World beside.
The Needle thus, too rudely mov'd,
Wanders, unconscious where;
'Till having found the place it lov'd
It trembling settles there.

div.stage: Going out starts back upon seeing an old Man dragg'd in by two Alguazils.

sp.p: Ha! what's here!

sp.speaker: Old Jew
sp.p: In mercy's name, allow me to escape,—I am old and not worth persecuting.

sp.speaker: Alguazils
sp.p: Old Sinners are the worst of all—come along

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: May I ask, Gentlemen, what functions do you bear?

sp.speaker: Alguazils
sp.p: Have you dropped from the Moon? We are Officers of the Inquisition.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Whither do you drag that poor old Man?

sp.speaker: Alguazils
sp.p: To a Dungeon to be sure.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: What is his Crime?

sp.speaker: Alguazils
sp.p: He is a Jew.

sp.speaker: Old Jew
sp.p: Oh! Sir—some secret Enemy has ruin'd me. I go to suffer Death ever without knowing my accusers.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Is he charg'd with no other Crime than this?

sp.speaker: Alguazils
sp.p: I tell you he is a Jew.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Is this the Country of Religion? [six or seven words inked out] shame on you, persecuting Hypocrites, release your Prisoner this instant.

sp.speaker: Alguazils
sp.stage: (eying him with derision and turning to his Companion)
sp.p: Here's a fine fellow for you. Why, where have you come from, young Hector? [two lines inked out]

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: What, do you back your cruelty with insolence? Villains—I'll shew you that one arm in the cause of Humanity is worth a hundred hirelings of oppression.

sp.speaker: Alguazils
sp.p: Here's rebellion against the Holy Office—down with him—down with him.

div.stage: (While they are fighting Rincon pops his head in)

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: [four words inked out]—Ho, ho— Alguazils, and Swords drawn. I'll not meddle here. Bravo, Alguazils—knock him down—knock him down—I'll not meddle—I'm off.

sp.speaker: 1st Alguazil
sp.p: Oh! I'm hurt—take to your heels—the dog has wounded me.

sp.speaker: Old Jew
sp.stage: (falling on his knees before the Gipsy Prince)
sp.p:
Generous Stanger! you have preserved my life, but your
own I fear will be the forfeit. You know not the powers of the Tribunal—to oppose it's Ministers is Death, and I fear you have wounded one of them—for Heaven's sake fly and preserve yourself. You carry with you the prayers of one who owes you his liberty and his life.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Thus runs my fate from one difficulty to another. Must I conceal myself? No—let them come—and yet—to be the sport of such ruffians—the thought is worse than death—this way seems to lead to the City. Let what will happen there is no one to weep for me!

div.head: Scene 3rd.
div.stage: One one side a Bower, and on the other a Turret. Enter Don Roderick and Don Dominick.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: As you say, my friend, I wish your boy Sebastian was here—he would just be a match for the Girl—but he's dead, isn't he?

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: Alas! I fear so,

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Then he'll not do for my Neice.

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p:
When my Brother went with the Missionaries to
the East, I unfortunately sent the Child along with him, an—

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Now have I heard this Story a hundred times—Ay, Well?

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: I sent my boy Sebastian with the Missionaries

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: And then lost him and he's dead or gone to the deuce; and you don't know what's become of him. Don't tell your old Stories so often, Brother Dominick, and you'll be a much more agreeable Companion.

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: Well, well, you are hasty, old Roderick—but, how is your Neice?

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: My Neice! very well—fine girl—but don't know what to do with her.

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: I say, marry her off your hands as fast as you can.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p:
That's what I wish, but the jade doesn't seem to know what Matrimony means—she has got an old broken winded guittar that I believe she'll be married to for the rest of her life (the guittar heard without). Ay,
here she is with that plaguy instrument of hers, the very curse of my life.

div.stage: Enter Antonia singing to the accompaniment of her Guittar.

lg.l: Sweet oh! sweet the Spring is coming,
Natures heavenly blush appears,
Stop oh! stop your cursed strumming,
Or you'll kill me thro' my Ears,
Bravo! delightful—
Bah! tis frightful—
Uncle, fye—'tis charming musick.
Neice, 'tis enough to make a Jew sick.
Repeat that air, Miss.
Do if you dare, Miss.
Sweet oh! sweet the Spring is coming &ca

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: A Prisoner has just been rescued from the Officers.

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: [two words inked out] Recued?—by whom?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: By a Stranger who has wounded one of them and escaped.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: What!—Rebellion against the Sante Officio? Oh! we'll tickle him, the dog! Catch him, and with our accustomed Civily, we'll give him his choice whether he'll be roasted or—boiled.

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: Come, Roderick. This offence is civil as well as religious We'll to the Alcaide, and order out a guard after him.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic

lg.l: Marry for money, for love or for mirth,
Take a Husband for use or for show'
'Tis better by far to lead one Ape on earth
Than perhaps lead a hundred below.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p:
How Uncle does abuse thee, thou dear companion of many a solitary hour (looking at her Guittar) he says
a husband would be a better play-thing—it may be so, but has a husband much musick in him?—Here are two, three, six frets—Ah! there are more frets in Matrimony than that, and then, one couldn't play upon a husband so easily

div.stage: (Archly, and striking the Chords of the Instrument)
The Gipsy Prince appears on the Walls of the Garden, looking back as if pursued.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: I am mistaken, I think—they were not Officers—yet they eyed me suspiciously—no matter—over I go. (jumps down) I cannot be worse than in the hands of those—(starts on seeing Antonia, who screams) A Woman! (advancing to her) Lady—if you can pardon such an intrusion—

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Pray, Sir, who are you, that thus—

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: I am a Stranger, Madam, but a few hours in Murcia. Passing thro' the Suburbs, I saw an unfortunate old Man, whom the Officers were dragging without mercy to a dungeon. I pitied, I rescued him. This offence, they tell me, is death—pursued, and flying, I know not whither—Heavens! how beautiful

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: But Sir, can you imagine—

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: I see that I offend. Yes, tho' looking thus is life, and death be without those walls, I go—

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Stay, Sir, what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Nothing for worlds that could a moment disturb you—if I might conceal myself in these gardens till night, the darkness then might suffer me to escape, but—

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: I have often wished for an opportunity to do good, now I have it, I will not lose it. (to him) Yes—Stranger, you shall have concealment here.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Oh! thus let me thank you, not for the life you preserve which is nothing; but for the feeling that warms you, which is every thing.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Heaven grant I feel no more than compassion—Will you be my prisoner?

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Yes, for ever.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Here is a little Turret—come you shall see it—(The go over to the Turret) There you may rest secure, & and as soon as it is dark—

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p:
Search the whole city for him. The
Corregidore will sit in the morning. [one line inked out]

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: My Uncle!—in—in, or we are [word inked out] ruined.

div.stage: Shuts him in the Tower and runs in trepidation to the Guittar.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Hey day! still at it? house, house, girl—it's growing late—Arn't you afraid of hobgoblins? They'll be dancing the blue devils' jig about you presently.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: True Sir (looking towards the Turret) when one is alone, strange figures will appear to one, as you say.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: What the Plague! you don't see anything appearing now, do you?

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir—go in—and I shall follow you—

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Pho! come along, Girl. I must be early in the morning.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Pray, Uncle—I have but to—but to look after my little bird in the Turret.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: A Bird in the Turret?—come, let's see—I like birds.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Dearest Uncle—no. You'll disturb it.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Not at all—no matter

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Besides, Sir, 'tis a Singing bird, & you're not fond of Musick.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Singing Bird, is it?—Oh! curse your singing—well, well—follow me immediately.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Hist! hist! but one word more. —(leads out the Gipsy Prince) there is a little bolt inside, by which you may command the door, and as soon as you think it dark enough to escape—but—but—is this the last time I shall ever see you?

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: First time and last!—Oh! that would indeed be too little.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Say you so?—and will you stay till morning here?

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Till morning?—Oh! 'twill be a blessed morning that brings you back to bless my eyes again.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: I am so happy!—as soon as it is dawn, I will come to you and the sound of the Guittar shall be the Signal for you to appear. Farewell, go to your lodging—I must after my Uncle.

lg.l: Good night, good night, I must away,
Altho' my heart would bid me stay.
Oh Lady, Say good night once more.
And I'll repeat it o'er and o'er.
Till the first glance of dawning light
Shall find us saying still "Good night"—
Good night—Good night!

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: The Gipsies Tents among the Willows almost dark.

lg.l: Where Gipsey gone? night stealing on
Come, come, come To the Willows fly
See now they creep from yonder steep
No fearee now de watchful eye.
Here we have spread in the Willows our bed
Fly, fly, fly—to the Willows fly—
Hush, hush, hum—Soft dey come
No fearee now de watchful eye—

quote.stage: (A Murmur of Gipsey-men, heard at some distance)

lg.l: Oh! Gipsey man, no care for wind,
In summer glow, or winter Snow,
Gipsey man no changes find

His Sunshine all is in de mind
.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Gipsies at a Distance.

lg.l: Hush, hush, hum—we Gipsies come—
Fly, fly, fly—to the Willows fly—
Soft we creep to our tents of Sleep
Sealed is now the watchful eye.

sp.stage: Gipsies entering in full burst of Chorus.

lg.l: Here, here, here—we Gipsies come &c.

sp.speaker: 1st Gipsy
sp.p: Where can this Prince of ours be? Something has happened him in the City, I am afraid.

sp.speaker: 2d Gipsy.
sp.p: Soft!—who comes yonder? Stand by—we'll sport him.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Dear me!—how busy I've been! helping the Alguazils all over the city to find that damn'd sacrilegious dog. Lord, lord—how anyone can meddle with the Inquisition! Women and the Holy Office—women and the Holy office are never to be meddled with.

div.stage: (Poppee & Lachimee come at each side of him)

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.p: How do you do, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lachimee
sp.p: How do you do, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Hey-day! talk of a devil, and two of them appear (looking alternately at them). Black—yellow—his livery at all events.

sp.speaker: Poppee & Lachimee
sp.p: Dear, dear, what fine dressy man! —see—see—nice fine

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Do you really admire this dress—'pon my Soul these Gipsies have no bad taste I find.

sp.speaker: Poppee & Lachimee
sp.stage: (pointing to different parts of his dress)
sp.p: give um dis, give um dat.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: What my hat?—what my Sword, eh! no, excuse me—

sp.speaker: Lachimee
sp.p: She got herself here, buddy Quonimo, here fine hat for you—

div.stage: (putting it on one of the Gipsey men)

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Oh! ho!—this is their taste for my dress—very flattering indeed—

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.p: Me very fond of you—love you plenty—you glad?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p:
Oh! certainly—very glad. Your love is extremely dear to me—and these are all keep-
sakes, you're taking, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.p: Iss—me wish fine bit of your hair, put in gold ring, eh?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: 'Twould be rather difficult, I believe

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.p: Oh! me find plenty look (pulls off his Wig and shews it round) See—here fine wig to put in a ring.

div.stage: (They all gather round him and seem emulous in tearing at his dress)

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: By my chastity, Ladies, you'll leave me not fit to be seen.

div.stage: The Alguazils rush in with the Opening of a Finale.
div.note: Song 9 ("In the name and glory of the Inquisitory") appears in witnesses a, b, and c, but not the ms. Click here to compare these witnesses.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.stage: The Gardens & the Turret. Enter Antonia with a Basket on her arm and a Guittar.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: How my heart beats! I hope they have not observed me. Oh! if my bird has not flown I shall be happy.

lg.l: Come from thy Cage, silly bird, dost thou hear,
Thy mistress is singing to thee.
Say, while she grants thee a Prison so dear,
Oh! cans't thou e'er wish to be free?
I knew by the Magic which stole on my ear,
That my mistress was singing to me
And while she grants me a Prison so dear,
I never can wish to be free.
Captive to thee, thus, and love
Where is the heart that could rove?

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Tell me, dear Stranger—

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Oh! say not stranger, call me—

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: What you will—(Sighs) I've never had a name. I never lived till now—(takes her hand affectionately) her lips should give the name, whose eyes have given the life.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: See, I have stolen this little basket of refreshments for you. I'm so afraid that Uncle will come this way—feel how my heart beats!

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: This is too much. I must not expose this innocent Girl to such dangers. —No, 'tis cowardly.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Come, we may venture to walk round yonder path, and then, my dear, dear Nameless, you shall tell me all your story.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Alcaide
sp.p: They have hunted him, your Excellency, all round the Suburbs.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Hunted him! ay, ay—they are fine beagles—after a Heretic—"Stole away—stole away!" is enough for them, but can they find no traces of the offender?

sp.speaker: Alcaide
sp.p: The found a party of Strolling Gipsies who arrived in Murcia but yesterday. Some of them they apprehended and others escaped—from their information we guess it must be their Captain, or Prince, as they call him, who committed this Murder

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Very likely these fellows think no more of poking a man's Guts than of stirring their fire—but Murder, did you say?

sp.speaker: Alcaide
sp.p: Yes, if the report be true which I heard this morning, that the Alguazil he wounded is dead.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Ferret him out, ferret him out—we must make a shining example—by the mass, we'll make an illumination of him. (During the latter part of this conversation, Antonia & Gipsey Prince Enter, but seeing Don Roderick, She steals to the Turret door, opens it cautiously while the Gipsey Prince gets in—just as she closes the door, Don Roderic turns about)—

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Hey day!—abroad so early, Antonia? What, with your pet in the Turret, eh?

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Yes, Uncle. I've been feeding it.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: What out of this (examining the Basket). Egad , your Pet has a prodigious good stomach.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Oh, Sir!—that—that basket belongs to the Gardener.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Ay, ay, so I thought—a fine swallow is the only bird that can manage that breakfast. Goodbye, Girl—I've death upon my hands to-day. This fellow that rescued the Jew must be Pickled. We Inquisitors shall go to the devil, if we don't send others in our places.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: And all this against thee, thou dear, unhappy wanderer! Oh! Heaven avert it, for I fear I cannot.

div.note: Song 11 ("Yes now I shall think of that heartbroken maid") appears in witnesses a, b, and c, but not the ms. Click here to compare these witnesses.
div.stage: Enter Rincon (beckoning as to someone without)

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Come, you little Gipsey—come into this Garden & I'll give you a kiss. What!—you won't eh? (Pulls in Poppee)

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.p: No—dis is not kissy day wid me.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p:
So, so—you've set days for kissing, have you? I suppose you're like the Thieves in Salamanca, whose piety will not let
let them steal on Sunday.

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.p: Iss—but me steal every day.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: The devil you do!

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.p: How fine Garden here—dis your garden all?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Yes—all mine—all (aside) Never laid eyes on it before.

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.p: Ha! what you got here?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: She's at it. She's at it.

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.p: Here good eaty man. Com me stop you mout dis way.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Ay, at, while my appetite is for her—Her appetite is for the breakfast. Let me see (goes to her) By my sobriety, Here's Wine—not a bad thing, Gipsey (drinks) What! eating meat on a Fast day—Oh fye!—see how I abstain from flesh and—if you don't come kiss me, I'll say you're a downright Heathen—Were you ever christen'd, you rogue?

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.p: No, Nebber—what dat?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Oh! Lord, Oh! Lord

div.stage: (He leads her forward & fills a Glass)

l.hi: Before then I fall to kissing you,
Here is a drop to baptise you;
Wine is the thing to Christen you,
May I ne'er have the luck to be tipsey

lg.l: If I an't in love with you dearly --
Love you, my sweet little Gipsey,
As well as my bottle—or nearly.
Oh! by the toe of St Nicolly
At Chee chee—you swear man.
I've such an itching to tickle you—
Tickle me! Ha!—you dare man!
What you come lie, you tinkee
I know not your love to a tittle,
Bottle trown by, when you drinkee,
And me, when you kiss um a little—
After you kissee and smackee once,
Woman still live to torment 'ee—
But de Ghost of bottle you crackee once,
No fear will rise up to haunt 'ee.

div.note: Song 14 ("Oh me was born to wander") appears in witnesses a, b, and c, but not the ms. Click here to compare these witnesses.
Song 15 ("Fye, fye, you're quite a sinner, girl") appears in witnesses b and c, but not the ms. Click here to compare these witnesses.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p:
There she goes—off with her—the feet of these Jades are generally as nimble as their Tongues, and old Nick himself can't keep pace with either. What's here? a Guittar?—Lord, if I had seen this while that little guinea-pig was here, I'd have soften'd her heart with a sequidilla in an instant. Nothing like musick for putting
crotchets in a woman's head—So—

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: At length you're come. Oh! welcome dearest—'Sdeath! we're betray'd! & ruined!

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Now shall I be kicked into the streets for my impertinence, and my Musick all end with a B. flat in the Gutter. Sir—(advancing) if I may be excused for this intrusion—

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: So, so, so—he is not of the family
sp.stage: (turns round to Rincon, who stares at and recollects him).

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Ho—ho—are you found at last, my Gentleman. Here's business for me—here's meddling to my heart's delight. I'll run to the Court this instant. Good morning to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: This fellow seems to know —I must detain him or I am lost—Stop, Sir

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Dear Sir—You're so pressing. I'll call again (aside) with a Guard.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Come, come, no trifling—do you see that Turret?—in there this instant: I must locklock you up.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Lock me up? Lord, Sir! (aside) Oh! The damn'd dog—he might as well take the bread out of my Mouth. Sure, Sir, you're not in earnest.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Peace fool—and do as I command —

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Oh! dear—well, if I must be lock'd up, just allow me, Sir, to take a companion with me
sp.stage: (takes the Bottle & Glass, and the Gipsy Prince locks him in)

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Where is Antonia!—but yesterday life was a burden to me, and now, love gives a value to every moment of existence—Ah! Antonia!

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: What shall I do? The guards are searching every where (looking towards the Turret) Oh! must I see thee torn from my Arms to a Dungeon? Never, never!—Hush!—I hear footsteps—something must be done instantly—(takes up the Guittar & hurries over the Strings). Come, come—(Rincon makes a noise within &ca) What can be the meaning of this? He cannot get out.

div.stage: (She unlocks the door. Rincon rushes out half drunk and catches her in his arms. She shrieks.)

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: That's right my little angel of deliverance—You let me out just in time, for I had nearly finished the last drop of my bottle.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Oh! Heaven—where is he?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p:
Hush, my dear—there's a damned sulky thief lurking here abouts—but don't be frighten'd—don't be
frighten'd, my love; for I'll bring a guard on him in five minutes

div.stage: (going towards the door—She follows him, seizes his Skirts and kneels)

lg.l: Oh! in pity hear me suing
By compassion's dearest sigh.
Ah! I see what she'd be doing,
Well, we'll talk on't by and by.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Dearest Sir—

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: The deuce is in it.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: But a minute—

quote.stage: (Enter Gipsy Prince just as Rincon is escaping)

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Stop, knave, at your peril stir.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Curse him, here he is again.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Back thou meddler, to thy den.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Oh! dear —

quote.stage: (NB.—during the Trio they lock Rincon up again and then Exuent.)

div.stage: (NB.—during the Trio they lock Rincon up again and then Exuent.)

sp.speaker: 1st Alguazil
sp.p:
From what the Peasant told us he must be hiding somewhere in this Garden (They search the bower) You may swear he has chosen the finest corner he
could find—(They look round the Stage).

sp.speaker: 2d Alguazil
sp.p: Let us try this Turret—(they unlock the door) What's here? a fellow fast asleep!—this must be he, seize him and carry him off.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.stage: (who wakes and comes out somewhat intoxicated)
sp.p: Lord bless me, what a dream I've had—stand off an I'll tell you—I thought a damn'd ill-looking fellow—very like you—(to one of the Alguazils) came and seized me by the throttle (the Alguazil seizes him) something that way but not quite so hard, and told me I should be hanged—

sp.speaker: 1st Alguazil
sp.p: So you shall be hang'd, you reprobate.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: My dream's out—isn't that comical?

sp.speaker: 2nd Alguazil
sp.p: Come along. You might well dream of hanging, after the murder you've committed.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Murder?—Let me recollect—No—I don't think I ever committed murder.

sp.speaker: 1st Alguazil
sp.p: Yes, but you have—no later than yesterday evening, and we've come to take you before the Corigidore.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p:
Do you mean me?—pon my Soul
gentlemen, I never was guilty of murder in all my life—its one of the things I never meddle with. I'm the most harmless man in Murcia—never committed Manslaughter or Suicide, except once upon a Pig—and I'll tell you you how that happened

sp.speaker: 1st Alguazil
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, you Heretic, and come along.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: By the noise, they must have been here—and, see! the Turret is opened. Now, on my knees I intreat you, determine something, or we are ruined.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Oh! that I could determine.

div.note: Song 17 ("Yes! for thee too charming Stranger") appears in witnesses a, b, and c, but not the ms. Click here to compare these witnesses.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: 'Tis death for me to stay, 'tis more than death to fly, while you remain behind—but will you, can you be the partner of a wanderer?

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: I shudder at the thought. Oh! do not urge me—go save yourself, and sometimes think of me.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: No, let them come—'tis sweeter thus to—

div.stage: (going to embrace her—some of the Officers rush in)

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Oh! Heavens—here they are!—

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: That is the Gipsey Prince.

sp.speaker: 2nd Officer
sp.p: And this is his protectress—force her from him.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Stand off—as long as there is a Pulse in this heart not one of you shall dare to seperate us—look up, Antonia.

sp.speaker: Antonia
sp.p: Yes—tho' I could not in life, at least I will follow you in death

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: And do you mean to resist going along with us?

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: No she revives. I am now at your disposal.

sp.speaker: 2nd Officer
sp.p: The lady must with us too

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: What!—are you chaining her hands? Cowards! Put all your fetters here (Shewing his own) You need not dread resistance from her—Come, Antonia—Lead on.

div.head: Scene 2. The Tribunal
div.stage: Don Dominick, Don Roderick, a Secretary. Guards attending with Rincon Prisoner—and Gipsies in fetters behind—Discover'd.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: In the Rue Larga did you say?

sp.speaker: Alguazil
sp.p: Yes, your excellency.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: By our Lady, the description agrees with my garden, perfectly—but that's impossible!

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: Well, Sir, you know the Offence for which you are brought here.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Not I, 'pon my Soul. —I say it in pure sobriety—I was to be sure a little bewilder'd with the bottle—but there is nothing like Alguazils for bringing a man to his senses, or indeed, frightening him out of them

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: Wasn't one of your gipsies seen to go into that Garden with you?

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: No, my lord, as I hope to be—yet stay—there did some little black thing creep in after me—but I assure you, the devil, black as it was, did not tempt me to any thing.

sp.speaker: Poppee
sp.stage: (running to him from among the Gipsies)
sp.p: Ha!—you call 'um devil, and you not member you want to kiss devil plenty, eh?—take dat, man

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Hey day!—my little Proserpine, between gown and Petticoat, I am in a pretty pucker.

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: To the point, Sir—Your rescue of the Jew from our Officer—

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: [word inked out] Phew!—(whistles and dances about) I have it now—I have it—my friend in the Turret—my friend in the Turret! damme, the wine washed it all out of my head. I'll tell your lordship—Here's meddling for me—

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
My Lord, the Gipsey is caught at last—the other party of Officers has found him, and the Lady who
concealed him. They are Prisoners without.

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: Bring in the Gipsey—let the Lady wait.

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: There now—business taken out of my hands again. Oh! if my head did not swim so often, what a man I'd be!—I'll tell you all, my Lord—

div.stage: (Re Enter Messenger with the Gipsey Prince fettered and Guarded)

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.stage: (Starts up on seeing him, and continues to look at him with earnestness.)

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Whatever punishment this Court prepares for me, I pray you only that it may be speedy, and for the Lady, whose humanity gave me an asylum, you cannot be so cruel as to injure her. —If she has erred in protecting a Criminal, humanity even in it's errors, is amiable; and—

sp.speaker: Rincon
sp.p: Humanity! Oh, Lord! my Lord, [five or six words inked out] the fellow was so humane as to be near cutting my throat about half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p:
His features!—Voice!—that Eastern dress, every thing confirms me—Young Stranger, be not surprised at my questions -
Where is your birthplace?

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: Where have you passed your life?

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: It's younger days in 'Ava.

sp.speaker: Don Dominick
sp.p: I cannot contain myself. Who were your Parents?

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: I never yet could learn—the earliest guardian I can remember, and [word inked out] him I too soon lost, was a Spanish Monk, who called himself my Uncle. His name—

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: Alvarez—Yes—(Embracing him) You are—you are my Sebastian—my long-lost darling Son.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: My Father!—And I, a criminal before him!

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: No, no—knock off his Chain. You are innocent of murder—the Man whom you wounded but slightly is recovered—and now—congratulate me Roderick, congratulate me, all. This is my boy—my Sebastian—is he not a fine fellow, Roderick?

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: Oh! very well, indeed! (aside) for a Vagabond.

sp.speaker: Gipsy Prince
sp.p: Father! I cannot shew half my happiness, while there is one dear wish of my heart left ungratified—this day gives me a Parent—but—there is another tie—The Lady—

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: By all that's miraculous—it's my Niece.

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: Antonia! why this is as it should be.

sp.speaker: Don Roderic
sp.p: So—this is your bird in the Turret, Miss?—a fine Cock-canary indeed!—You Jade to [word inked out] go shelter a Heretic, a—

sp.speaker: Don Dominic
sp.p: Stop, Roderick, he is now my Son, and your Niece may assist us to convert him.

div.note: Song 18 ("The Gipsey Prince no more shall roam") appears in witnesses a, b, and c, but not the ms. Click here to compare these witnesses.
